thread.title: London weather: Capital set for more rush hour snow after evening of transport chaos

author: Barney Davis, Tom Powell
title: London weather: Capital set for more rush hour snow after evening of transport chaos
text:
Snowfall in London January 2017 1/6 
A cyclist makes his way through the snow near Tower Bridge PA 
Commuters were caught up in long delays due to the weather at Waterloo station 3/6 
Cars covered with snow at Tring station 4/6 
Tring was carpeted with a soft blanket of fresh snow last night 5/6 
There were short flurries of snow in the City PA 
Two women take shelter under their umbrella during light snowfall in central London PA 
Commuters faced an ice-cold journey into work this morning with more snow forecast and temperatures barely rising above 1C. 
The Met Office described last night’s freeze as the “first taste of winter” and has predicted more cold conditions for Friday morning. 
There were also warnings of further disruption for motorists as sub-zero overnight temperatures could lead to hazardous conditions on the roads. 
It came after a night of chaos on the capital’s transport network as the first snow of the winter descended in parts of London. Snow falling near Tower bridge on Thursday night as London had its 'first taste of winter' (PA) 
There were huge crowds and long delays on South West Trains services at Waterloo while Canary Wharf was evacuated due to a flood. 
Central Line passengers were also hit with delays as a faulty train at Holborn led to closures at Bank and Oxford Circus Tube stations. 
Meanwhile, 80 flights were cancelled at Heathrow Airport and four at Gatwick Airport. Waterloo station was rammed on Thursday night due to delays on South West Trains services (@JamesJWalsh) 
A Met Office spokesman said: “Yesterday we saw rain turn into sleet and then wet snow which accumulated away from the heat of the city centre causing serious disruption, particularly in the south. 
“Light snow is expected again around 9am and just after rush hour. It will be a light covering of snow, short-lived and done by lunchtime when it will turn dry with sunny spells.” 
However, the sky is expected to clear slightly and let the sun in from late morning. Snow in London 
There are fears that the weather conditions may also badly affect Tube and train services. 
Mick Cash, general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union, said: "A combination of staffing and maintenance cuts means that rail and Tube services are running on a knife edge at the best of times. 
"Any adverse weather conditions are almost guaranteed to tip us over that edge." Wintry flurries: Snow at Couldson station, south London (Sam Hill) 
Snow began to fall in parts of south London including Kingston, Croydon and Bromley as the Thursday evening rush hour began. 
It was followed by flurries in parts of north and west London including Hampstead, Muswell Hill, Islington and West Brompton. Commuters battle transport chaos as snow lashes London 
Photos also showed people sheltering beneath umbrellas as they made their way through a snow flurry in the City of London. 
Thousands of rail passengers were delayed when a Waterloo-bound train broke down causing a queue of trains to back up. 
Charity worker James Walsh, 33, from Ladywell said: “There were hordes of people causing a jam at the top of the escalators, it was a real safety issue. Brave Londoners walk outside during a snow flurry at Bank on Thursday night (PA) 
“There were lots of frustrated commuters but no staff around to help. I think it shows how much money rail operators spend on their services if a drop of snow can cause so much chaos.” 
Actor Matt McMaster, 33, said he couldn’t move through the “sea of people” at the station. 
He said: “It literally felt like it snowed for 15 minutes. I was thinking how Canadians wouldn’t bat an eye lid at that. Everyone was full of resentment and resigned to these mammoth queues.” 'London will not grind to a halt if snow strikes', TfL tells commuters 
Air passengers were left stranded as Heathrow Airport cancelled 80 flights before a single snowflake had fallen. Four BA flights from Gatwick and 29 flights at City airport were also grounded. 
Frank Atton, 62, a sign-maker who has worked with McClaren and Manchester United’s Old Trafford stadium was forced to spend the night in a hotel instead of arriving in Switzerland for a skiing holiday with his daughter . 
He told the Standard: “I have O-level Geography and I know we could’ve taken off there was hardly any cloud density. 
“The decision to cancel those flights is frankly ridiculous, a complete overreaction which is something that happens in this country. 80 flights were cancelled at Heathrow Airpot due to predicted conditions (Dan Kitwood/Getty Images) 
“I have taken off in Detroit in a blizzard, at -10 degrees and it was absolutely fine. 
It comes after driving snow, high winds and ice hit large parts of the UK, disrupting travel and closing schools. 
Today the Met Office has issued severe weather warnings across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland for combinations of high winds, snow and ice. Tring station covered in snow on Thursday night (Jeremy Selwyn) 
The Environment Agency's 12 severe flood warnings - which warn of a danger to life - are in place for Friday lunchtime in coastal areas of Essex and Suffolk in the face of gale-force winds and high tides. 
Thousands of residents of Jaywick, Essex, were this morning braced for evacuation from predicted flooding from high winds and heavy rain. 
As darkness fell in the seaside village on Thursday night, a flood siren could be heard and police had been handing out evacuation advice leaflets to residents. 
The letter warned that if they decide to remain in their homes, there is a "high risk" their properties "could be flooded by sea water up to a depth of three metres". 
"If flooding does occur then it is anticipated the emergency services will be stretched to their capacity and may not be able to undertake emergency rescue until the flood water has subsided," it added. A beach in Jaywick, the Essex village being evacuated today amid severe flood warnings (PA) 
It is understood that some people have already left Jaywick, while others will be leaving before midday on Friday - with some refusing to move. 
Police are thought to be using a colour coded system to identify those staying put and those who may be vulnerable, so that if flooding occurs they can prioritise who to help. 
Pete, 42, a man who has lived in Jaywick for nine years, said he thought the flooding "will be worse than two years ago". 
Quizzed about his thoughts on the expected deluge of sea water, he said: "You get used to it, that is what everyone will say around here. It is part of living by the coast." More about:
